abstracts.cdata!:
The overall assessment of the project is
            unsatisfactory. Although the establishment of research
            programs, which gave way to new technologies for the
            development of basic crops was a success, and, the training
            component resulted in a positive performance, the project
            however, show negligible achievements in its institutional
            development and poverty alleviation objectives. In addition,
            the project's overall achievements do not convey a
            sustainable likelihood. The key lessons learned show that, a
            long term commitment by governments should be required, in
            spite of government changes which may occur, given the long
            term nature of research programs. Attention should be given
            to achieve well defined research programs, particularly
            where critical areas are involved. While management
            continuity is essential for a successful project
            implementation, management, and monitoring and evaluation,
            are considered key elements in project performance. Salary
            scales ought to be in line with those of other civil service
            staff, to prevent political interference in agency staff
            appointments, which could possibly divert attention from
            professional qualifications. Above all, management and
            technical staff selection criteria, should be respected.
            Risk identification at the appraisal stage should be closely
            monitored, with well defined solutions, should risks occur.

18153927.trustfund:
TF034850-BOLIVIA - AGRICULTURE TECHNOLOGY,TF023715-BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION
            PROJECT (BCP),TF020350-DANISH CONSULTANTS TRUST FUND

abstracts.cdata!:
The project has two main objectives.
            Firstly, to improve the overall efficiency of research and
            extension and, secondly, to directly support technology
            development in the highland agricultural sector.  The
            project will establish a Consejo Nacional de Investigacion y
            Extension Agropecuaria (CNIEA) to more effectively
            coordinate research and extension in the country as a whole.
            The project will also strengthen the national agricultural
            research agency, the Instituto Boliviano de Tecnologia
            Agropecuaria (IBTA), and focus its efforts on developing
            technology suitable for smallholders in the highlands.  The
            new IBTA will be reorganized on the basis of commodity
            programs, and be charged with overall responsibility for
            developing agricultural production, processing and marketing
            technology, and for demonstrating its technical, economic
            and social viability within the constraints of the rural
            conditions.  The commodities to be researched will be:
            potato, cameloids, sheep and forage, maize, small grains,
            grain legumes (Faba beans and peas), and quinoa.
